body: It's sad, the vigil. More so, however, because r_c knows {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} should care, but {VERB/r_c/don't/doesn't}, rather than any grief for m_c.
r_c is called to m_c's vigil, but declines to speak. {PRONOUN/r_c/subject/CAP}{VERB/r_c/'re/'s} not sure {PRONOUN/r_c/subject}'d have anything nice to say.

{PRONOUN/r_c/subject/CAP} know {PRONOUN/r_c/subject}{VERB/r_c/'re/'s} supposed to be distraught, but r_c simply isn't. The bad blood between them outweighs any sibling bond {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} might have had with m_c.
Maybe r_c would have mourned m_c, once upon a time. After all, they are siblings. But not this time, not now.

m_c was always displayed on a golden pedestal, regardless if trouble arrived because of {PRONOUN/m_c/object}. No cat ever noticed m_c's flaws, not in the way r_c sees them. But whenever r_c made a single mistake, suddenly everyone's eyes shot open and paws pointed to shamed {PRONOUN/r_c/object}. So, what better time than now? With m_c's death, r_c takes with a glint in {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} eyes to brag about m_c's accurate appearance.

From the day they were born, r_c has always been m_c's shadow. It didn't matter if the two were trained under the similar sky; {PRONOUN/m_c/subject} were always everyone's favorite cat, leaving r_c to barely nibble at the leftover crumbs of half-hearted praises and appreciation. When the funeral was finished, r_c takes the chance to unbury the body, hoping the maggots would love {PRONOUN/m_c/object} just as much.
